texts.shortText: Dorsally flattened with eight shell plates articulating on its dorsal side, surrounded by a soft fleshy girdle. Girdle wide, covered with small spicules and greenish bristles interspaced with larger ones. Nine tufts of long, glassy spines are characteristic. Middle plates subtriangular to rhomboid-shaped. Texture of shell with small oval granules and fine striae. Colour dark grey or brown with white central line or a pair of lines. Articulamentum dark brown, grey or green with large anterior shell extensions.
Medium, typically around 10-20 mm total body length, but large specimens reach 45mm.

Global: Mauritius, Reunion and South Africa. Reports from WoRMS and other articles from Fiji and Venezuela cannot be confirmed.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.

On exposed rocks and crevices from the inter- to mid tidal zone. Unusual among chitons in that occurs in the open, rather than concealed under boulders. The spines can cause skin irritation, so animals should be handled with caution.
Herbivorous - rasps algae off the rocks using its radula.

External fertilization releasing eggs and sperm into the water. Eggs develop into planktonic trochophore larvae that metamorphose and then settle as juvenile chitons. The egg hull is formed by microapocrine secretions instead of exocytosis of Golgi vesicles. When fertilization occurs, the sperm digests a pore in the egg hull and releases its DNA.

The related A. variegata occurs from False Bay to Bhanga Nek but has lower and less dense granules. These are more prominent on younger individuals while valves can be heavily eroded in adults. A. variegata is a more cryptic species than A. garnoti.

Blainville, HMD de (1825). Oscabrion, Chiton, pp. 519-555, in: Dictionnaire des Sciences Naturelles (F. Cuvier, ed.), vol. 36. Levrault, Strasbourg & Paris, & Le Normant, Paris.

Kilburn, RN & Rippey, E (1982) Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg, xi + 249 pp. (p. 137).
